lexUnit.name: purge.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: remove by a cleansing process.

sentence.text: The exodus appeared to reflect Croat efforts to purge Muslims from Croat-controlled districts ahead of a possible agreement to divide the Bosnia into Croat , Serb and Muslim ministates .
We can purge this disease from the countryside ! "
Unlike them , he does have the chance to come out and lead his troops in person , purging any doubts about his leadership with the sheer , naked courage of his performance .
The Pill was as much about men 's sexual liberation as it ever was about women 's , because it purged their fear of paternity .
The sin of the world was purged by the waters of the flood .
It was as if Lucie 's pride had been purged away by standing in that vat of swirling morning mist .
It was strange , but his hatred was purged .
Modernism may well have been purged from public view , but to the determined specialist it was still covertly available .
When participants in the latter are purged from the statistics we find no real growth in the period 1983 to 1986 .
So they switched off one side of their brains in order to purge fatigue poisons from their systems while the other cerebral hemisphere remained alert for intruders …
Mr Jakes , it is not forgotten , purged 600,000 from the 1.5million party and many more from other sensitive positions .
He regarded Lexandro musingly as a brother might a sister whose honour he must protect -- a sentiment which Lexandro had purged from his own soul , though he recognized the symptoms .
Those who had escaped were immediately purged to other camps .
The permanent staff was gradually purged to other camps until there were none of the original ` old people " left .
